concepts.title: Answer only what the question asks

questions.text: Including extra philosophical material shows comprehensive knowledge.
questions.explanation: A good response addresses only what the question asks and no more. Including superfluous material distracts from your argumentative contention and can result in unfocused responses.
questions.studyTip: Read the question. Answer that question. Stop.

questions.text: High-scoring responses provide complete answers limited to what the question requires.
questions.explanation: Students who keep their focus tightly managed avoid bringing in irrelevant material. Complete answers that directly address the question score better than sprawling responses.
questions.studyTip: Quality of argument beats quantity of content every time.

questions.text: Repeating the quotation in your own words shows you understand it.
questions.explanation: A significant number of responses repeated verbatim the quotation or elements of the extract. This doesn't demonstrate understanding—it demonstrates you can copy. Explain what it means and why it matters.
questions.studyTip: Don't echo the quote. Analyse it, apply it, evaluate it.

questions.text: You should interpret and analyse quotations rather than simply restating them.
questions.explanation: Low-scoring responses often cited Descartes' observation without citing his conclusion, or restated parts of extracts. Show you understand the philosophical significance, not just the words.
questions.studyTip: Quote → Explain meaning → Show philosophical significance.

questions.text: If you've written a good explanation earlier, you can reference it in later questions.
questions.explanation: A significant number of students cited—verbatim—responses they had given in another part of the examination. Each question requires a fresh, appropriate response. Copying loses marks.
questions.studyTip: Each question = fresh answer. No recycling.

questions.text: Each question requires its own appropriate response, even if topics overlap.
questions.explanation: Some students made mistakes in earlier questions that were then repeated when they copied material. Tailor each response to what that specific question asks.
questions.studyTip: Even if topics overlap, craft each answer to fit its specific question.

questions.text: Focusing exclusively on the extract ensures your response is relevant.
questions.explanation: Many students lost sight of the question and focused exclusively on the extract. You must be cognisant of both the extract AND the prompt. The question tells you what to do with the extract.
questions.studyTip: Extract provides material. Question provides direction. You need both.

questions.text: Responses must address both the extract and the specific question being asked.
questions.explanation: Students are reminded to ensure responses are appropriate to the requirements of the task. Working with an extract doesn't mean ignoring the question—the question frames how to use the extract.
questions.studyTip: Keep checking: Am I answering THIS question using this extract?

questions.text: Supporting your evaluation with what you personally believe is appropriate justification.
questions.explanation: Many students equated evaluation with discussion of their own views, supported by personal beliefs (e.g., 'I think X because I believe Y'). This is not philosophical justification—it's assertion.
questions.studyTip: Not 'I believe...' but 'This argument fails because...'

questions.text: Evaluation requires testing arguments with examples and counterarguments, not stating beliefs.
questions.explanation: Evaluation is the process of testing arguments, using examples and counterarguments to uncover merits and shortcomings. Show WHY a viewpoint should be considered favourably or unfavourably.
questions.studyTip: Evaluate = test the argument. Your job is to probe, not pronounce.

questions.text: Articulating an argument more clearly counts as evaluating it.
questions.explanation: A significant number of students simply articulated the argument they were evaluating a second time. Restating an argument doesn't evaluate it—you must assess its strengths and weaknesses.
questions.studyTip: Restating isn't evaluating. Where does the argument succeed? Where does it fail?

questions.text: Evaluation requires assessing the merits and limitations of an argument.
questions.explanation: The marking criteria ask: 'Did the student evaluate the merits and limitations of selected arguments?' Identify what works, what doesn't, and why.
questions.studyTip: Evaluation = merits + limitations + reasons for each.

questions.text: Examples are optional extras for philosophy responses.
questions.explanation: There was a noticeable dearth of examples, even in mid-scoring responses. Examples are explicitly included in the marking rubric. They're not optional—they're essential for testing arguments.
questions.studyTip: Examples are in the rubric. No examples = marks lost.

questions.text: Examples are essential for illustrating claims and testing arguments effectively.
questions.explanation: High-scoring essays test ideas through effective examples and compelling counterarguments. Examples illustrate claims and reveal whether arguments hold up in concrete situations.
questions.studyTip: Every major claim should have an example that tests or illustrates it.

questions.text: A short evaluative paragraph before the conclusion is sufficient.
questions.explanation: Evaluation tends to be addressed in a cursory manner, usually with a short paragraph before the conclusion. High-scoring essays engage in sustained critical discussion throughout, not just at the end.
questions.studyTip: Evaluate throughout, not just at the end.

questions.text: High-scoring essays engage in sustained critical discussion throughout the response.
questions.explanation: Critical discussion should be woven through your essay, testing ideas as you present them. Don't save all evaluation for a final paragraph—integrate it with your exposition.
questions.studyTip: Present argument → Test it → Move to next argument → Test that too.

questions.text: Identifying what a philosopher would think about an issue is sufficient.
questions.explanation: Students could identify plausible positions from philosophers' perspectives, but many did not explain WHY the philosopher might adopt this position. More space needed for articulating arguments for claims.
questions.studyTip: Don't just state positions. Explain the reasoning behind them.

questions.text: High-scoring responses explain the arguments supporting a philosopher's position.
questions.explanation: It's not enough to say 'Aristotle would think X.' You must explain the arguments that lead Aristotle to that position. Show the philosophical reasoning.
questions.studyTip: Position + because + argument = complete response.

questions.text: A general understanding of a philosopher's main ideas is sufficient for the exam.
questions.explanation: Many responses included approximations or caricatures of philosophers' arguments—particularly Aristotle's mean, Nietzsche's noble/slave morality, and Wolf's reasons of love. Nuance and accuracy are essential.
questions.studyTip: Generalities won't cut it. Know the nuance in each philosopher's position.

questions.text: A nuanced and accurate grasp of philosophical arguments is essential.
questions.explanation: Accurate understanding is essential not just for exposition but for effective evaluation. If you misunderstand the argument, your evaluation will be flawed.
questions.studyTip: Misunderstand the argument → Misfire on the evaluation.

concepts.title: Aristotle's mean applies to virtues only

questions.text: Aristotle's mean can be applied to anything—we should use technology neither too much nor too little.
questions.explanation: Students often discussed technology as a 'mean' to be handled with moderation. Aristotle is clear that the mean only applies to virtues. Technology itself is not a virtue—how and why we use it may relate to virtue.
questions.studyTip: The mean applies to character states, not to things like technology.

questions.text: Aristotle's doctrine of the mean specifically applies to states of character, not to external things.
questions.explanation: Many students demonstrated misunderstanding by treating the mean as simply 'not too much or too little' of anything. The mean concerns virtuous character traits, not objects or activities.
questions.studyTip: Mean = virtue of character. Not 'moderation in all things.'

concepts.title: Use philosophy to think, not just include

questions.text: Including lots of philosophical material demonstrates strong knowledge.
questions.explanation: Some students included material without discrimination, resulting in unfocused essays. Philosophy should further the discussion meaningfully, not just be present because it's required.
questions.studyTip: Don't dump philosophy in. Use it to think through the problem.

questions.text: Philosophy should be used to think through and develop your response, not just be present.
questions.explanation: High-scoring responses utilise philosophy as a means to further the discussion, not just include it as a requirement. Philosophy is a thinking tool, not decoration.
questions.studyTip: Ask: How does this philosophical idea help me answer the question?

questions.text: Nietzsche values suffering because it helps us learn from our mistakes.
questions.explanation: Less effective responses claimed suffering allows us to 'learn' and avoid mistakes, or develop empathy. Nietzsche's view is about suffering producing greatness and character—not lessons or empathy.
questions.studyTip: Nietzsche: suffering → greatness. Not suffering → learning lessons.

questions.text: Nietzsche values suffering for its role in developing greatness and character.
questions.explanation: Nietzsche believes suffering is generative to individual and social greatness. High-scoring responses explored how eliminating suffering might undermine human potential for self-overcoming.
questions.studyTip: Know WHY Nietzsche values suffering—it's about human greatness.

questions.text: Stating your position clearly is the same as justifying it.
questions.explanation: Many students provided a series of assertions without justification, or justified with personal beliefs. Justification appropriate to philosophical discussion requires reasoning and evidence, not just clear statements.
questions.studyTip: Assertion ≠ justification. You must give reasons.

questions.text: A justified response provides philosophical reasons supporting the position taken.
questions.explanation: Justification means showing why your position should be accepted through philosophical reasoning—arguments, examples, and logical connections, not personal preferences.
questions.studyTip: For every claim you make, ask: What's my reason? What's my evidence?

questions.text: Explaining which philosopher you prefer and why is a justified response.
questions.explanation: Quite a number of students discussed which philosopher's views they preferred and why, rather than providing a justified response to the question. Preference isn't the same as reasoned justification.
questions.studyTip: The question isn't 'which philosopher do you like?' Answer the actual question.

questions.text: A justified response addresses the question directly, not just which philosopher is preferred.
questions.explanation: Comparative evaluation (which philosopher is better) is different from a justified personal response to the question. Make sure you're answering what's asked.
questions.studyTip: Justified response to the question ≠ preference for a philosopher.

concepts.title: Go beyond summary to critical engagement

questions.text: Demonstrating you know the philosophers' views is the main goal.
questions.explanation: Many essays took the form of systematic information dumps about philosophers, with vague allusions to the topic. Knowledge must be applied critically to the question, not just displayed.
questions.studyTip: Don't show off what you know. Use what you know to answer the question.

questions.text: Responses should apply philosophical knowledge critically to address the specific question.
questions.explanation: Having a clear through-line turns your essay from an expression of information into an exploration of philosophical ideas. Apply your knowledge, don't just demonstrate it.
questions.studyTip: Information dump = low marks. Critical application = high marks.

questions.text: Covering all the relevant philosophical material ensures a good essay.
questions.explanation: Students who detailed everything they'd learned rarely had a clear through-line. Having a clear and focused goal was consistently a mark of good thinking and high-scoring responses.
questions.studyTip: What's your argument? If you can't state it in one sentence, clarify it.

questions.text: High-scoring essays develop a precise contention that guides the entire response.
questions.explanation: A focused argumentative thread turns information into exploration. Your contention should be evident throughout and every paragraph should advance it.
questions.studyTip: Every paragraph should serve your contention. If it doesn't, cut it.

concepts.title: Use extracts in detailed, specific ways

questions.text: Mentioning the extract in your introduction fulfils the requirement to use it.
questions.explanation: Many students discussed the extract in the introduction then never referred to it again. Others used extracts in cursory or generalised ways. Detailed, specific engagement throughout is required.
questions.studyTip: Extract shouldn't just appear in the intro. Weave it throughout.

questions.text: High-scoring essays engage with extracts in detailed and specific ways throughout.
questions.explanation: High-scoring responses made specific and well-developed use of extracts in the construction and delivery of their response. Short quotations from extracts ensure responses remain relevant.
questions.studyTip: Quote specific phrases from the extract. Return to it multiple times.

questions.text: Discussing the extract and then separately discussing the philosophy is an effective structure.
questions.explanation: Students struggled to weave concepts from extracts into meaningful exploration using philosophy. Extract-then-philosophy compartmentalisation doesn't show integration.
questions.studyTip: Don't separate extract from philosophy. Make them speak to each other.

questions.text: Effective essays integrate discussion of the extract with philosophical analysis.
questions.explanation: Developing a response that integrates the extract and the philosophy in sustained evaluation is challenging but essential. Use philosophy to analyse the extract's claims.
questions.studyTip: Formula: Extract claim → Philosopher's perspective → Your analysis.

questions.text: Presenting your argument clearly is more important than considering objections.
questions.explanation: The marking rubric values counterarguments. High-scoring responses presented counterarguments convincingly. Considering objections strengthens your argument.
questions.studyTip: What's the best objection to your argument? Address it.

questions.text: High-scoring essays consider and respond to counterarguments.
questions.explanation: Examples were well chosen and compelling; counterarguments were presented in a convincing way. Acknowledging and responding to objections shows philosophical sophistication.
questions.studyTip: Present objection → Respond to it. This shows you've thought it through.

concepts.title: Write only about ONE philosopher (unless specified)

questions.text: Including both philosophers from the prompt shows comprehensive knowledge.
questions.explanation: A number of responses were written on both philosophers when only one was required. For many, this was poorly managed and the second philosopher didn't further the discussion meaningfully.
questions.studyTip: Read the prompt carefully. Usually it's ONE philosopher, not both.

questions.text: If the prompt specifies one philosopher, additional philosophers should only be included if they meaningfully advance your argument.
questions.explanation: Including extra philosophers without discrimination results in unfocused essays. If you include additional philosophical sources, they must genuinely further your discussion.
questions.studyTip: Second philosopher = only if it genuinely helps. Otherwise, stay focused.

questions.text: Discussing philosophical concepts abstractly demonstrates understanding.
questions.explanation: Students struggled with questions requiring active consideration of concepts and their application to examples. Philosophy must connect to concrete cases to demonstrate genuine understanding.
questions.studyTip: Can you give an example? If not, you might not understand the concept.

questions.text: Genuine understanding involves applying philosophical concepts to concrete examples.
questions.explanation: Questions requiring application of concepts to examples of students' own making were challenging. Prepare by practising applying every concept to real-world cases.
questions.studyTip: For every concept you learn, prepare two concrete examples.

questions.text: A general understanding of what an extract is about is enough to respond.
questions.explanation: Students struggled to accurately read and understand previously unseen philosophical ideas. Section B requires genuinely considering and applying concepts from extracts, which was rarely done well.
questions.studyTip: Read the extract multiple times. What exactly is it claiming? Why?

questions.text: Engaging with extracts requires careful attention to their specific claims.
questions.explanation: Many students neglected detail in extracts and wrote generalised essays on the broad topic. Pick out specific claims and engage with them directly.
questions.studyTip: Underline specific claims in the extract. Respond to those exact claims.

questions.text: Nietzsche's master/slave morality distinction is his main contribution to ethics.
questions.explanation: Work with Nietzsche was rarely more than generalities about master and slave, lacking critical commentary or nuance. His philosophy on suffering, self-overcoming, and greatness offers more depth.
questions.studyTip: Nietzsche is more than master/slave. Know self-overcoming and suffering too.

questions.text: Effective use of Nietzsche requires understanding beyond the master/slave distinction.
questions.explanation: Students most comfortable with Nietzsche could discuss self-overcoming, the generative value of suffering, and human greatness—not just master and slave morality.
questions.studyTip: What does Nietzsche say about greatness? About suffering? Go deeper.

questions.text: The 'bourgeois' criticism of Wolf attacks her objective requirement.
questions.explanation: Low-scoring responses confused the bourgeois criticism with problems about Wolf's objective requirement. The bourgeois criticism is specifically about meaningfulness being a concern only for certain privileged people.
questions.studyTip: Know the specific criticisms of Wolf. They're different from each other.

questions.text: The bourgeois criticism of Wolf concerns whether meaningfulness matters to those without basic needs met.
questions.explanation: Wolf acknowledges her view might be considered relevant only to people from 'a certain place, time and social class.' This is distinct from criticisms of her objective requirement for meaning.
questions.studyTip: Bourgeois criticism = is meaning relevant to everyone? Know this challenge.
